values.description:
Fix gazebo (and ros image_transport) crashes due to image publication race condition. Happens when publishing image before params are initialized. 

Can be reproduced around 1 in 3 times by launching `vrc_task_*` with  ros_subscribers. Just add the line below to a `vrc_task_*` launch file:

`<include file="$(find atlas_utils)/test/ros_subscribers.launch"/>`
values.title: Check camera util is initialized before publishing

summary.raw:
Fix gazebo (and ros image_transport) crashes due to image publication race condition. Happens when publishing image before params are initialized. 

Can be reproduced around 1 in 3 times by launching `vrc_task_*` with  ros_subscribers. Just add the line below to a `vrc_task_*` launch file:

`<include file="$(find atlas_utils)/test/ros_subscribers.launch"/>`
summary.html:
Fix gazebo (and ros image_transport) crashes due to image publication race condition. Happens when publishing image before params are initialized.

Can be reproduced around 1 in 3 times by launching vrc_task_* with ros_subscribers. Just add the line below to a vrc_task_* launch file:

<include file="$(find atlas_utils)/test/ros_subscribers.launch"/>

values.description:
This pull request adds two tutorial packages:

* `atlas_interface_bridge`: contains a ROS node that links against libAtlasRobotInterface.  It provides the familiar ROS message API provided by drcsim but on the back communicates with the real robot.  It's currently very incomplete, but can be easily filled in by somebody with physical access to a robot.
* `atlas_interface`: contains a library that implements the same API as libAtlasRobotInterface but on the back end communicates with drcsim via ROS messages.  It is also incomplete, but has actually been tested by a team that has a robot.

Together, these tutorials offer a couple of different ways that teams can migrate their code back and forth between hardware and simulation (#337).  They're provided as source code tutorials and not compiled by default because they require the AtlasRobotInterface SDK to be installed.
values.title: Add tutorials for hardware / simulation bridging (#337)

summary.raw:
This pull request adds two tutorial packages:

* `atlas_interface_bridge`: contains a ROS node that links against libAtlasRobotInterface.  It provides the familiar ROS message API provided by drcsim but on the back communicates with the real robot.  It's currently very incomplete, but can be easily filled in by somebody with physical access to a robot.
* `atlas_interface`: contains a library that implements the same API as libAtlasRobotInterface but on the back end communicates with drcsim via ROS messages.  It is also incomplete, but has actually been tested by a team that has a robot.

Together, these tutorials offer a couple of different ways that teams can migrate their code back and forth between hardware and simulation (#337).  They're provided as source code tutorials and not compiled by default because they require the AtlasRobotInterface SDK to be installed.
summary.html:
This pull request adds two tutorial packages:

  • atlas_interface_bridge: contains a ROS node that links against libAtlasRobotInterface. It provides the familiar ROS message API provided by drcsim but on the back communicates with the real robot. It's currently very incomplete, but can be easily filled in by somebody with physical access to a robot.
  • atlas_interface: contains a library that implements the same API as libAtlasRobotInterface but on the back end communicates with drcsim via ROS messages. It is also incomplete, but has actually been tested by a team that has a robot.

Together, these tutorials offer a couple of different ways that teams can migrate their code back and forth between hardware and simulation (#337). They're provided as source code tutorials and not compiled by default because they require the AtlasRobotInterface SDK to be installed.

values.description:
Addresses Issue #143.
(Merged pull request #370).

See documentation on [RoadMap](http://gazebosim.org/wiki/DRC/Roadmap).

Needs testing.

To test:
~~~
mkdir catkin_ws
mkdir catkin_ws/src
cd catkin_ws/src
hg clone #!/osrf/osrf-common -r catkin
hg clone #!/osrf/sandia-hand -r catkin
hg clone #!/osrf/drcsim -r catkin
git clone -b groovy-devel https://github.com/ros-simulation/gazebo_ros_pkgs.git
~~~

For example, `ls catkin_ws/src` should show 4 repositories:
~~~
osrf-common
sandia-hand
drcsim
gazebo_ros_pkgs
~~~

To build:
Assuming all system and ROS dependencies have been installed:
~~~
cd catkin_ws
source /opt/ros/groovy/setup.bash
catkin_make install
~~~
should do the job.  To run something, try:
~~~
cd catkin_ws/install
source setup.sh
source share/drcsim/setup.sh
roslaunch drcsim_gazebo atlas_sandia_hands.launch
~~~


John
values.title: catkinize drcsim with new atlas model (catkin drcsim 3.1.0 candidate)

summary.html: Change current behaviour of use cp to install AtlasSimInterface in /usr during compilation and use project paths to compile against it. Install the AtlassimInterface using standard install comands and CATKIN variables.

values.description:
I am considering the following use cases:

1. Catkin workspaces installations (currently broken for the need of root perms to install /usr/share/drcsim/setup.sh)
1.  System from source installations
1.  Deb package generation

In 2 and 3 we want to keep setup.sh into /usr/share/drcsim/setup.sh while in 1 we don't want it at all. Another way to control this would be to introduce a building parameter to install it or not, but then magic won't happen anymore automatically for all cases.

@gerkey do you see any flaw to this hack besides it is just this, a hack?
values.title: Install setup.sh in /usr only if PREFIX is /opt/ros in order to respect catkin ws

summary.raw:
I am considering the following use cases:

1. Catkin workspaces installations (currently broken for the need of root perms to install /usr/share/drcsim/setup.sh)
1.  System from source installations
1.  Deb package generation

In 2 and 3 we want to keep setup.sh into /usr/share/drcsim/setup.sh while in 1 we don't want it at all. Another way to control this would be to introduce a building parameter to install it or not, but then magic won't happen anymore automatically for all cases.

@gerkey do you see any flaw to this hack besides it is just this, a hack?
summary.html:
I am considering the following use cases:

  1. Catkin workspaces installations (currently broken for the need of root perms to install /usr/share/drcsim/setup.sh)
  2. System from source installations
  3. Deb package generation

In 2 and 3 we want to keep setup.sh into /usr/share/drcsim/setup.sh while in 1 we don't want it at all. Another way to control this would be to introduce a building parameter to install it or not, but then magic won't happen anymore automatically for all cases.

@gerkey do you see any flaw to this hack besides it is just this, a hack?

values.description:
What is this pull request implementing:

* New USE_ATLASSIMINTERFACE_BLOB cmake argument to control the use of AtlasSimInterface library.
* Check for support in 32bits Linux archs, if 32bits support is found, fail the cmake and ask to use the new  USE_ATLASSIMINTERFACE_BLOB=False to be sure users will know what's going on.
* In BSD archs, let's assume 64bits but warn users about this non implemented check.

All the API is kept, just make the functions using the binary lib to be empty.
values.title: Support for free AtlasSimInterface buillds (on by default for 32bits)

summary.raw:
What is this pull request implementing:

* New USE_ATLASSIMINTERFACE_BLOB cmake argument to control the use of AtlasSimInterface library.
* Check for support in 32bits Linux archs, if 32bits support is found, fail the cmake and ask to use the new  USE_ATLASSIMINTERFACE_BLOB=False to be sure users will know what's going on.
* In BSD archs, let's assume 64bits but warn users about this non implemented check.

All the API is kept, just make the functions using the binary lib to be empty.
summary.html:
What is this pull request implementing:

  • New USE_ATLASSIMINTERFACE_BLOB cmake argument to control the use of AtlasSimInterface library.
  • Check for support in 32bits Linux archs, if 32bits support is found, fail the cmake and ask to use the new USE_ATLASSIMINTERFACE_BLOB=False to be sure users will know what's going on.
  • In BSD archs, let's assume 64bits but warn users about this non implemented check.

All the API is kept, just make the functions using the binary lib to be empty.

values.description:
Catkin isolated builds are currently broken on default (to reproduce, use catkin_make_isolated instead of catkin_make). This fixes it.

Also, add gazebo dependencies in package.xml to allow catkin_make_isolated builds with gazebo from source.

UPDATE: Clean up drcsim_gazebo_ros_plugins/CMakeLists.txt

values.description:
The drc_practice launch files use the wrong bringup file which gives a bunch of errors about parameters.

There's also some specific fixes for task 6. The cutout_wall model was being installed to the wrong location and couldn't be found. Also the launch file and world file hadn't been updated to match the style of the other practice tasks.

summary.html:
The drc_practice launch files use the wrong bringup file which gives a bunch of errors about parameters.

There's also some specific fixes for task 6. The cutout_wall model was being installed to the wrong location and couldn't be found. Also the launch file and world file hadn't been updated to match the style of the other practice tasks.

`handle_msgs::HandleSensors` message is initialized to zero for now.

`handle_msgs::HandleSensors` message is initialized to zero for now.
summary.html:
This needs gazebo pull request #735 with Joint::SetStiffnessDamping function in gazebo's issue_845_spring_damper branch and gazebo pull request #737 gearbox joint branch to work.

handle_msgs::HandleSensors message is initialized to zero for now.
